context: His first professional TV job came when he was hired to direct one of the segments for the <a4_0><a5_0><b10_0><b11_0><b14_0>1969<b14_0/><b11_0/><b10_0/><a4_0/> pilot episode of Night Gallery<a5_0/>. The segment, "<b12_0>Eyes<b12_0/>," starred <a0_0><a6_0>Joan Crawford<a6_0/><a0_0/>; she and Spielberg were <a3_0>reportedly close friends<a3_0/> until her death. The episode is unusual in his body of work, in that the camerawork is more highly stylized than his later, more "mature" films. After this, and an episode of Marcus Welby, M.D., Spielberg got his first feature-length assignment: <a1_0><a7_0>an episode of The Name of the Game called "<b13_0>L.A.<b13_0/> 2017"<a7_0/>.<a1_0/> This <a8_0>futuristic <a2_0>science fiction<a8_0/><a2_0/> episode impressed Universal Studios and they signed him to a short contract. He did another segment on Night Gallery and did some work for shows such as <a9_0>Owen Marshall: Counselor at Law<a9_0/> and The Psychiatrist, before landing the first series episode of Columbo (previous episodes were actually TV films).
